div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m., for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai)El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.

div.head: BEEF TRUST SCANDAL.
div.p: The ' Daily Telegraph's" New York corres poudent writes that after protesting with might and main again t the proposed Govern- ment inspection, the Chioago meat paokers, who are fairly typical of man£ other American packets, have saddenly discovered that they are absolutely yearning for inspection, the more, in faot, the better. This attitude, he learns, is doe not to any great awakening of conscience regarding the aoousations of buying diseased cattle and exporting dangerous pro- duots to various quarters of the earth, more particularly to the United Kingdom, which has long been the favourite damping ground, bat to ominous reports from abroad, which foreshadow a heavy loss of trade. The paokers, in faot, throughout the country are described as being fairly frenzied with fear, prodaced partly by the knowledge th t the Argentire Republic, which is their next competitor in the export ot meat prodaots, will undoubtedly benefit by the present oatory, and also that Canada, which might very well supply those same products, will wake up, as ehe is doing,

This whether the British peblic, who are a most morning opens beautifully clear with a strong north- • . . , t . erly breoze and a rising barometer. I Important factor, will wake up, iemails to be ' seen. Some of the hardened packers have rather a poor opinion of the British consumer, and believe that when the present glare of publicity is withdrawn, and when the usual questions ia the British Parliament have been asked and answered, he will forget all about the diseased meat, putrid livers, dyed and deodorised hams, and canned atrocities which have figured so largely io the present scandal. There have been revelations about canned beef and venal inspectors before, and they have always been "lived down," so why not thia time 1 The Beef Trust people are well represented in New York and in Europe, and they will doubtless be able to prove "conclusively" to a confiding pablio that the Chicago packing houses are the best in the world, and that the system of inspection already existing absolutely safe- guards the consumer. Germany and France have made the distri- bution of dangerous meat prodaots from abroad praotioally impossible, but the British, despite all statements to the contrary, are not nearly so striot as they ought to be, and as the necessities of the public health demand. Fig- ures are published,showing the enormous trade in meat products done by the United States with the United Kingdom, the trade in similar prodaots with other oountries, such as France, Germany, and Italy, being absolutely insigni- ficant by oomparisoD. These figures were farnibhed by Mr. Seymour Bell, the British Commercial Agent at the British Consulate- General in New York. For the ten months eading April, 1906, the United Kingdom took £809,000 worth of canned beef, and no beef, it is ominoas'y explained by Mr. Upton Sin- clair in his investigation, is oanned "if it is good for anything else." Of hog products, the United Kingdom, in a similar period, took over £4,500,000 worth. Franoe and Ger- many did not take maoh over £250,000 worth between them. The trustful Britishers are credited with spending nearly £3,0 0,000 for American hams, over £1,300,000 for salted and fresh canned pork, while for lard they paid nearly £3,l00,u00. These are only some of the figures from the trade aocount of American meat products exported to the United Kingdom. They all relate to the ten months ending in April last and in most instances they show a tendency to increase substantially. Most, if not all, the items go from the packing houses, which are now so bitterly attacked, not by the British consumer, who has hitherto been largely in the dark, but by Americans, who say that they stand in still greater need of protec- tion than the foreign oonsumer. It will be interesting to oompare the figares for the next three months, now that people are thoroughly alarmed, with the corresponding period last year, when trade was bcoming. There is a demand now, not only for the strictest inspection of the stookyards and of meat throughout the country, but for officials who will withstand the system of ' graft," the American equivalent to bribery, corruption, and illicit oommissior, which it is not disputed is a paramount evil in the United States at the present day. Unless the inspector be above "grafr," it is obvious that his services, instead of being a pablio beuefit, become a positive pablio danger. At Chioago there is a story told of one inspector who not only failed to inspect, but spent his entire time in studying medicine. It is a different class of inspection and inspector which the country demands, and one who will refase to sell himself to the Beef Trust

div.head: CHEAPER MUTTON
RESULT OF BAD BARLEY CROP.
div.p: The Mariout barley orop has suffered so much this year from the want of winter rain that the Bedouins of the whole district as far as Ain Hammam have been obliged to sell a large proportion of their flocks. No less than 1,700 sheep arrived at the Bah Sidra market the day before yesterday, and large consignments arrive regularly, with the result that the price of mutton has fallen considerably. Syrian mutton now costs from P.T. 7 to P.T. 8 per oke, while the price of Egyptian mutton has fallen from P.T. 13 to P.T. 9 per oke.

div.head: REGISTRATION OF SERVANTS
div.p: We are informed that the notice recently published by the police authorities re the re-gistration of servants was, in effeot, merely a repnhlioation of a notice published in January, I904, in Arabic and Frenob, and widely circulated by the polioe. As long ago as September 15, 1902, a law was passed forbidding ' placenrs" of servants to place servants who were not in possession of snch oertifioates. To render this law operative, employers of domestics, bowabs, gardeners, etc., must support the authorities by refusing to engage any servant who does not hold a certificate of identity bearing his photograph and his signature or seal. A servant is not legally oompelled to hold such a certificate bat employers oan insist on his doing so in the manner above indicated. As soon as the Berberee finds that without a certificate he oan get no place, he will take care to furnish himself therewith. The police notice was as follows : - "In view of the Deoree of Sept. 15, 1902, the public is info'med that the agents for the placing of domestics are forbidden to offer any domestic for employment who is not provided with a certificate of idettify renewed yearly by the Police and with another cerificate giving the nature of his employment and the cause of his dismissal. These two certificates must bear the photograph and seal of the domestic in question. 'The publio is urgently requested to employ no domestics but those who are in possession of the above-mentioned certificates. The same measare is adopted in the oase of the lower ranks of employes, buwabp, gardeners, etc. They should therefore be asked for their papers before berig taken into service, i "This measure has bren taken to safeguard individual interests as well as in the interest of public security." We commend this notice to our readers. If it were generally followed we are confident that the "servant qnestion" would be far more easy to deal with.

div.head: DAMIETTA AGAIN.
div.p: PETITION TO LORD CROMER.

The following is the text of a petition submitted yesterday to the Earl of Cromer by the members of the Damietta delegation : — Cairo, June 7th, 1906. My Lord, — We respectfully beg to be allowed the honour of tendering our hearty thanks for the attention lent by yonr Lord- ship to the Damietta question, for the courteous letter to the Delegation, the meeting granted to our representative, and the compromise unfolded in the oom- muniqad published by the Ministry of Interior. We beg, however, to point ont that acoording to the said communique this compromise leaves the principal cause for complaint unchanged, for Damietta by the new arrangement will be a Govbtncrffie 'ib name and a district of,the Dakahlieh Province in practice, communicating with the Ministry through the Moodir of another Province instead of having direct and in dependent means of oommnnioation as heretofore. We need hardly say that this new roundabout way of transacting the public business of Damietta will lead to much worry and delay. This will be needlessly wasted and interests thereby jeopardized. It appears to ns that the decision of the Government was fonnded upon erroneons information, for if the oonvenienoe of the rural districts around our city was the main Danse of the recent change as the communique shows a mere glance at the map will alter this view. By the new arrangement Damietta is the oentre of a rural district of which one end is at a distance of 15 kilometres from this centre and the other end is some 57 kilometres distant. The northern part of the new Markaz is a mere strip of coast with only five villages, while the other part south of Damietta is a vast district with 38 villages nine-tenths of of which were nearer to the old oentre of local government at Farsoour. These villages will surely suffer instead of benefiting by the change. Special mention of the villages north of Damietta has been repeated in the oommunique. These as already Btated are only five villages which have always been considered suburbs or even quarters of our oity. We would gladly welcome any change that may ameliorate the condition of these villages, bat they have always been governed from Damietta in all matters of administration and pnhlio security and have never had oause to oomplain. For rates and taxes they were considered part of the Dakahlieh Province, hat the one single employe for this branch of publio work, a Sairaf, lives at Damietta. We have gone through these details in order to show that the recent change had no real raison d'etre. We of ooorse do not oomplain of the addition of some villages to our own distriot. On the contrary we appreciate and belaud this beneficial ohange. But the thing we complain of is the degredation of our ancient oity from the rank of a separate province to that of a rural village in the Dakahlieh Province. The glory of our ar cient oity to which you kindly referred on meeting onr representative will vanish and we humbly pray you to complete the reform begun at our request and eave Damietta from the degredation and ruin that threaten it through the new arrangement. We leave the whole matter to your Lordship trusting that our just demands will be granted io the near future. We beg to remain, My Lord, Yoar humble and obedient servants, MEMBERS, DAMIETTA DELEGATION. A similar petition has been addressed by the Delegation to the Adviser at the Ministry of the Interior. Certain inhabitants ot Damietta yesterday despatched telegrams to Lord Cromer, Mr. Maohell, the deputation, and several Cairo newspapers, stating that they find the new arrangement made by the Ministry is by no means satisfactory. They hope that their representatives will oontinue their work until the Gonvernorat has been placed directly under the Ministry of the Interior, as before.

div.head: RIVAL SHEIKS IN THE YEMEN
div.p: A STORY OF MURDER. Constantinople, Wednesday.— Ahmed Faizi Pachp, oommanding the troops in the Yemen, has telegraphed to the Government oomplain - ing of the failure to send reibfjroemeuts. He adds that the situation is disquieting owing to the extraordinary preparations made by the insurgents, who are organized in regiments and battalions like a regular army. Daring the last few days the Gosernment has been sending considerable sums of money to Ahmed Faizi Pacha. A ramour is reported to-day from Hodeidah to the effect that the Imam Yahya, leader of the insurgent tribes, has been murdered by an emissary of his rival, Sheikh Kassim.

div.head: THE TALUDI INCIDENT.
div.p: We understand that no white troops have been sent to Talndi in connection with the reoent riot, nor is there any intention of sending any.

div.head: NEW SUDAN ROADS.
div.p: The "Sudan Times" states that a road 8 metres wide has been constructed between Singa and Tigo, a distance of 18 miles, while another road has been opened between Tigo and Gehel Sereig, a distance of 30 miles. In consequence of the opening of these roads the journey from Goz-Abcn-Guma to Singa takes only three days instead of the ten that were formerly required.

div.head: MOTOR CAR DANGER.
div.p: It is reported that the Government intends to introduce a series of regulations for the drivers of hired motor oars. If the Capitulations allow of it we should like to see all drivers of motor oars, motor omnibuses, vans, etc., oompelled to hold certificates of profi- oienoy. The very amateur driver of the dogcart is too well known in Cairo and Alexandria, and the advent in large numbers of the enthusiastio but inexpert motorist will add a new terror to our streets. The French Government, we believe, refuses licences to chauffeurs who have failed to pass a practical examination in a large quadrangle strewn with prostrate lay figures. If a wheel toaches any of these, no license is accorded.

div.head: MUKHTAR PACHA.
div.p: Apropos of the open letter to Mnkhtar Pacha recently published in our columns, "Al Lewa" demands the name of "the impertinent Taik who has the insolence to read a lesson to the ohief of the Marshals of the Empire." Onr confrere oonclndes by saying that these attacks against the Ghazi only prove more olarly what eminent services he has rendered to the Otto-* man Empire.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF WORCESTERSHIRE REGIMENT.
div.p: The 4*ffi Battalion of the Worcestershire Regiment, which arrived from Malta on the 11th ptoxo. in oonnection with the recent Anglo-Tnrkish orisis, and has been under oanvas since at Mnstapha Pacha, will embark for Malta to-morrow on the R.I.M.T. Dafferin. The transport arrived at Alexandria to day at 1.80 p.m. from Malta and moored at berth No. 41.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: T.H Princes Hnssein Pacha and Kamel-el- Din have returned to Cairo. - ' Baba Pacha will return on or about the 18th instant from Rome. Mr. Dupuis left Cairo for Khartoum on Wednesday night. The departure of Colonel 0. Todd.R. A.M.C., for Bombay has been postponed. Captain Thomas Dalby, King's Royal Rifle Corps, has been seconded for service with the Egyptian Army. —i— M. Maroel Chariot is staying at Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo. Mr. Reginald Silley, barrister-at-law, who practised before H. B. M.'s Supreme Consular Court of Constantinople, is now in Alexandria, and has joined the offices of Messrs. Briscoe and Aioard. Mr. Silley has held many briefs, and has always been successful. His thorough kbbwledge of the East and its languages specially, adapts him for dealing with litigation between different nationalities. Dr. James Ferguson Less has heed authorised to fctaotise in Egypt. Mr. Thomas Roberts, Representative of British Industries, who has been on a visit to Alexandria, left yesterday by the Italian mail boat Teto for Naples.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Suite et Fin.) La Commission adopte les propositions da Comite spdoial charge de l'^tude de la question de Exchange deterraios avco le Goavernement sur les quais, 6chinge destind A attribuor cortaines parcelles des terrains des quais h l'Etat pour la construction des ^iifioos n sairea a sea administrations centre d'antres terrains et d'ao tree edifices Loader A la Municipality, dchange laiasant an soldo en fa voir de celle-ci de L.E. 2174 environ. Mention est faite de l'envoi aux Membres des propositions de l'administratenr concer- nant la reorganisation du service technique municipal par une centralisation de l'adminis- tration de ce service aujonrd'hni r4partie entre divers bureaux et la decentralisation de l'exe oution an moyen de l'institution d'ingenieurs divisionnaires. Apr£s un echange d'idees et vu 1'avis favo-rable de la Delegation, la Commission donne mandat à PAdminiatrateur de mettre à execution ce projet de reorganisation dans la toesure que permettent les dispositions da rkglement interieur. La Commission pfend connaissance de Pavia da Oomite du Contentieux au sujet de l'iiitro- daction à Alexandria de la viande oongefee. Adherant aux propositions formates par fe servioe à ce sujet, le comite propose de sou- mettre 6ette introduction aux conditions sui- vantes : lo. Droit de visite des agents mueicipaux dans les locanx de sejour de la viande con- geiee. 2o. Production d'nn oertificat d'origine deii- vre par un vUterinaire ayant one position offi- oielle et attestant qne i'animal a ete visite de son vivant et trouve en bonne saute. 3o. Droit pour la Municipality d'imposer tontes prescriptions oonoernant l'bygikne an cas d'une installation frigorifique. la Comite a estime en dernier lien qti'une redevanoe est due en remuneration du service des agents de la Municipality, redevance qu'il appartient à la Commission de fixer. La Delegation en emettant un avis favorable à cette proposition, propose de fixer à 3 mil- lfemes cette redevanoe et d'imposer aux touchers et antre3 qui debiteront de Cette viande one marqae speoiale pour la distinguer des autres viandes. La Commission adopte les conclusions du rapport du Comite du Contentieux, et decide de les imposer par voie d'arrete, en fixant à 3 millikmes la redevance et en etablissant les sanctions voalues au cas d'indbServation des conditions imposees. Les debitants de la viande congeiee devront indiqaer par one enseigne qn'ils font le commerce de cette viande. Sar le rapport de la Delegation, et en con-sideration da but hamanitaire poursuivi par le chiakhat des Ulemas d'Alexandrie, la Com-mission coDsent à deduire da prix des echkohes da Wardian doDt la oession à oe chiakat avait ete preoedemment decide**, le prix de la mos- quee et fixe à L.E. 2,000 le moutant à payer la dite institution religieuse com me dedommsge- ment à la Municipality ; Par la proposition de lk Delegation, la Com-mission deride l'ouvertare des oredits snivants: L.E. 30, à prelever sur le budget extraordi-naire, poor la reparation de la toitnre du bureau des moeurs. L.E. 100, à prelever sur la reserve du budget ordinaire, pour la reparation en Angleterre de la pompe automobile. L.B. 100, à prelever sur le budget extra-ordinaire poor la oreationd'nn posts provisoire des pompiers à lTbrahimieb. LE. 60, à titre soppiementaire, à preiever sur le budjet extraordinaire, pour l'aohat de plaques destinees au recensement des oharettes à mains et des hicyclettes. Uo medit soppiementaire de LE. 418 pour fourniture8 de bureau et imprimes ainsi qa'an oredit suppiementaire de LE. 300 pour seooars aux families d'employe? deoedes et autres sdnt renvoyes à l'examen du comite des Finances. Deux demandes de credit dont l'un de L.E. 1500 pour la construction d'nne noofelle salle d'abattage et l'autre de LE. 2540 pour les tra- vaux de terrassement de la route de 30 metres snt toute sa largenr, dont L.E. 1238 dejk vo- tees par la Commission, sont renvoyees à l'examen des comites des Finances et des trkvanx publics reunis. Statuant sur one demande de denomination d'nne rue, la Commission decide de snrseoir à oette demands, attendn qu'il oonviendrait que les propositions de denomination de rues fujsent presentees en one eeale fois etkane epbqae determines de l'annee, aprds une etude d'ensemble du Comite des Travaux Publios. Adoptant l'avis de la Delegation, la Com-mission fixe à P.T. 3 par metre carry, la redevance fortaitaire à payer par la Compagcie des Tramways pour l'entretien des parties de la chanssee, daliees on asphaltees, traversees par 80s lignes et dont ©lie a la charge. La redevanoe pour les routes macadamisees sera de P. P.T. 1 par metre. L'arrangement à oon- olure sur cette base, ptoduira ses effets pour la duree d'une anuee senlement, dura nt la- quelle la Municipality pourra se rendre compte si oe nouvel arrangemeut sauvegarde see intents. La stance est levee à 7 h. 1/4 p.m.

NOTES HT CRITIQUES Le Cairo, Jeadi 7 Jain. LQ taux de l'esoompte libre k Londres reste toajeara in varik & 3 1/2 pour cent. Hier, an Stock Bxohange, le Consolidk anglais a baissk de 1/8 à 89 3/8. L'Unifike a cldturk en haasae de 1/8 à 104 1/2. La National Bank a rkaotionnk de 1/8 k 25 7/8. L'Agri- oole eat demenrke inohangke à 9 7/8, de mkme qae la Delta Light à 12. La Daira a perdu 1/4 de livre à 17 1/4. A Paris, l'aotion Crkdit Foncier Egyptian a regagnk 1 franc à 774. La Bvnqae d'Athines eat restke k 158. Ioi, nous avons eu, oe matin, un marohk absolument oalme, aveo des affaires encore plus olairsemkes qn'hier. La tendance eat tonjours à la lourdeur, sinon à la faiblesse proprement dite. La plupart dea cours sont reatka stationnaire?, faute de transactions; d'aucuns ont subi de lkgires moina-valuep, gknkralement dkterminkes par dea realisations faites en vue de l'exode estivale. L'opinion predominate eat que lea derniers echelons de la baisse sont sur le point d'etre descendas et qu'une reprise pourrait se produire plus vite qu'on ne le pense. Le fait est qu'il serait imprudent de perdre de vue, d'une part, la situation saine du marohk, ainsi que l'abondanoe de l'argent, et, d'autre part, les prix, devenos rkellement tentants, d'une grande partie de nos valeurs. La National Bank a ktk ramenke à 25 3/4 et VAgricole à 9 5/8-11/16. La Banque d'Athknes a cldture 156-157 et la Banque d'Orient à 130. L'aotion Credit Foncier est restke à 774 ; la partde fondateur a reculk à 1,000. La Daira s'est maintenue à 17 1/8-3/16 et la Delta Light à 12 1/8. La Bkhkra s'est alourdie à 35 8/4-36. La part de fondateur Wardan Estate a encore perda 5/8 à 7 1/4. La part de fondateur Nile Land a baissk de 92 à 85. L'aotion Enterprise and Development a'est raffermie à 12 la part de fondateur a, par contre, flkohi à 16 1/4. Les Jouissanoes Eaux da Caire ont regagne 2 francs à 259. L'Heliopolis a ete traitee à 285 et la part de fondateur à 8 3/4. Les aotions privilkgikei Tramways d'Alex andrieont faibli à 178, ex ooupon, et les dividend* à 333, ex-ooupon ; les Ciments à (0. Dans le gronpe des Hotels, les Nungovioh ont ete ootks 15 (ex-ooupoD) l'aotion ancienne et 15 3/32 la nouvelle. Les Baehler ae sont maintenus à 5 5/16 et les National ont pro- gresae à 3 3/8-7/16. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates ont ete faibles à 1 9/16; la part de fondateur a rk aotionne à 9 1/2. Les G'ymenopoulo ont ete offerts à 1 1/2-9/16, les Abdy à 1 5/16 et le Nile Cold Storage à 0 1/2-9/16. Les Sucreriea sont restees à 27. L'assemblke extraordinaire des aotionnaires de la Nile Cold Storage Co, tenue bisr dans l'apris-midi an Caire, a ratifik les resolutions prises à l'assemblke precedente du 19 Ma;. relativement à la reduction du capital aooial de £ 50.003, oe qui ramknera la valeur nomi nale de l'aotion de £ 1 à 16 shellings. Dans UDO etude sur les ktablisaements de credit etrangers r.ka de l'initiative anglaiae, le correspondent londonien da "Monitear Intkrkts Materiel a" de Bruxelles fait remarquer que la diminution dans le benefice de la National Bank of Egypt en 1905 a'explique par les avantages extraordinaires que cet'e institution a retires de ees placements en 1904 En rkalitk, sea operations de banque proprement dites ont ete plus fruotueuses en 19f 5 qu'en 1904. L'eorivain ktablit ensuite, par des ohiffres, que la capitalisation de la National Bank of Egypt (5 15/16) est basse et que le cours de ses aotions oomporte l'escompte d'an aooroisso- ment prochain des dividendes. Nous dktaohons d'ane lettre deLondrea, eD date du ler Jain, les lignes suivantes : "La Banque d'ADgleterre continue à tra vailler aveo snooks à la reconstitution de sa reserve monetaire ; elle draine à oet effet vers sea oaisses pre? que tout ce qui arrive sur le marohe. Or, tant que cette reserve ne sera pas revenue à un niveau norma), la Banque non-seulement n'abaissera pas son taux d'es oompte, mais n'admettra pas que le taux de l'esoompte libre soit sensiblement rkduit. "C'est lk la question qui interease le plus en ce moment notre marohe financier. Sa solution pourrait seule, en effet, donner aux affaires du Stock Exchange l'eisor que l'on attend vainement depuis la disparition des nudges noirs d'Algksiras et d'Akaba." L'assembiee generate extraordinaire de Compagnie Immobilikre d'Egypte du 26 Mai dernier n'ayant pas reuni les trois quart da capital, les aotionnaires sont oonvoquea k nouveau pour le samedi 30 Juin oourant, i Bruxelles, à l'effet de dklibkrer sur les rksoln tions provisoires suivantes adoptees le 26 Mai L'assembiee decide à l'unanimitk de modi fier le ler paragraphe de Particle 26 des Statuts comme suit: " L'assembiee generate ordinaire est tenue " cheque annke dans le oourant de Mai ou de " Join. Cette decision sera appliquee k l'assem " bide generate ordinaire de 19 )6. " Les aotionnaires de la Splendid Hotels of Egypt Co. sont oonvoques en assembles generate ordinaire pour le vendredi 22 Join oourant, à 4 h. 30 p.m., au New Khedivial Hotel k Alexandrite. A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil d'ad ministration ; approbation des oomptes et fixation da dividends, s'il y a lien ; nomina tions statutaires, etc.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT. Liverpool, May 31. Tin demand for Egyptian on the spot has again been very small. Q lotations, however, of Good Fair and Fully Good Fair Brown are raised j per lb ; the better qualities are unchanged. Upper Egyptian is per lb. lower. In Futures only a moderate business has been done, and the following are the latest quotations :— Aug. 9.53 Nov. Sept. 9.40 Deo. Oot. 9.25 May — Jane 10.7 July 9.59 8.48 8.36 8.25 J merican Futures. The Market this week opene 1 firmer, and prices advanced 5 to 6 points ; later, however, the tone became weak, and with considerable pressure to sell prioea have deolined sharply, to day's dosing values being 15 points lower for Old Crop, and 9 points lower for the New Crop positions, than those of last Thursday. The deoline was ohiefly due to Bulls liquidating, Bear manipulation, and improved Crop accounts. The general expectation appears to be that the Bareau report, to be issued on the 4th proximo, will be much more favourable both as regards the increase in the acreage, and the condition of the Crop, than the unofficial estimates have indicated ; for the confirmation of this we await the report itself. At the deoline, which is 24 @ 28 points in two weeks, we have a rather favourable opinion of the artiole. The following are the latest quotations :— June 5.79 Sept./Oct 5.65 Jan./Feb. 5.60 June/July 5.79Oot./Nov 5.61 Feb./Mar. 5.61 July/Aug. 5.79Nov./Deo. 5.60 Mar./Api. 5.62 Aug/Sept. 5.73 Dec./Jan. 5.60.

div.head: TURKISH POWER IN ARABIA. FOREIGN INFLUENCES. IMPORTANCE OF KOWEIT
div.p: a European Power the Ottoman Empire viftly dec'ined during the last century, one ooald judge of it from the modem hib^ry r-f tin Arabian Peninsula, one might thick that the Turks are still a conquering aDd advancing race. It was only after the opening cf the Suez Canal that they conquered the fertile province of Yemen. When I travelled to Sanaa, its aoc:ent capital, in the autumn of last year, the coantry was largely depopulated by a great famine and a great revolt ; but there wap, nevertheless, an enormous amount of oultiva- tion, chiefly of coffee and doura, and the sides of the mountains, which reach the height of 10,COO feet, were sometimes entirely oovered from top to bottom with well-made terraces Later on the Turks annexed the oases of Hasa, and within the last two years they have gained a certain degree of authority over the Arabs of Nfjd. While they have lost in Europe they have gained in Arabia ; and though they are almost invariably hated or despised from Aden to Baghdad, revolution is not so inevitable among theSemitio subjects of the Sultan as it is among European peoples, like the Greeks and Bulgarians. WAHABISM. The increase of Turkish power in Arabia "J flowed the decline of that great wave of Puritan fanatioism known as Wahabism. Led by Emirs of the family of Sand, the Wahabis united the greater part of Arabia under one powerful rule, and resisted the Egyptian armies of Ibrahim Pacha. Bat the capital of the Sands was at Riad, in the southern part of Nejd, and they governed Jebel Shammar, in the north, through deputies who lived at Hail. One of these, named Raschid, made himself independent, and in the la1 ter part of the list ciatury the Emir of Riad were nsoally hard pressed by the Emirs of Hail Recently coati .^ed fighting has made the exploration / Central Arabia almost impossible; bat c_en Mr. Wilfrid and Lady Anne Blunt visited Jebel Shammar in the great days of Mahomed ibn Rasohid, they foand peace and crdei sternly enforoed by that strong and unscrupulous ruler. Pew powerful States have been so completely is Hated as Mohamed's ephemeral kingdom, and to this day, in spite of that incomparable book of travel, Doughty's " Arabia Deserts, " and several romantic accounts of Europeans who penetrated the interior of the Peninsula, many people still imagine the whole country to be an unbroken wilderness. In the last two years there has been another greater reversal of fortanes in Nejd. There is bat little Wahabism left, bat the present Ibn Saad has completely triumphed over Ibn Raschid. the nephew of Mohamed, who was lately driven for a timeout of Hail itself. The conqueror has now unpatriotically determined to secure his viotory by admitting Ottoman troops into some of his towns, and although these are mostly deserting, and arriving at Koweit in miserable plight, there is at last some apt earanoe of reality about the suzjrainty of the Sultan. The Turks have sometimes supported both parties at the same time, bat until the reoent events they were usually regarded as the friends of Ibu Raschid, while Shaikh Mubarak of Koweit was the ally of Ibn Sand. Ibn Raschid, however, is said to have pnt them in the front of the battle—an honoor wh'ch they did not appreciate, and, in any case, they have abandoned him now that he has ceased to be formidable. The present agreement was come to at a meeting between Ibn Sind, Mubarak, and the Vali of Basra. Foreign inflaenoe in Arabia is shared by the Turks and the English, and the Arabs realise that, while the Tnrks usually take, the English sometimes give. Ibn Sand appealed in vain for English protection before he allowed Aneyzi to be garrisoned by hnngry soldiers of the Saltan; and though certain Sheikhs probably have little love for ns, they know that, without ns, they would be at the meroy of a more greedy enemy. LOCAL TRADE. The trade of Arabia is largely carried on y natives of India, and almost the whole coast-line from Aden to Koweit is more or less under the protection of the Indian Government. The petty chiefs of the Aden territory and the coast of Hadramnt, if they are not always obedient to the British, are certainly obedient to no one ehe. The Saltan of Oman enjoys a British sub.-idy, and is, on the whole, our faithful ally but be has not mnoh authority over his Bedouin vassals outside Muskat, who are liable to be influenced by our French rivals. The so called "Trucial Chiefs" of the pirate coast have long looked for pr iteotion snd advice to the British Resident at Bushire, while the Sheikhs of the Peninsula of Katar owe more a'legiance to the Tarks than to UP. river the valnable pearl islands of Bahrein, claimed both by Turk-y and Perria, we bold & definite position of supremacy, as Shaikh Kiau and his successors are bound by treaty to have no dealings with any other Power. Here, as at Muskat and Koweit, the Government of India has established a political •fjercy, sr.ri there is also a small force of Sepoys; but the Sheikh is supposed to be entirely independent in internal affairs, and i fanily and servant who are Sannis, bru- tal y ill-treat the natives of the two islands we Shiahs The coast of Hasp, with the town of Katif, is purely Turkish, bat over Koweit we have recently acquired a certain undefined influence, and Sheikh Mnbarak owes his independence to British gunboats. Here, and eleewhere in the gnP, oar policy has lately been mnoh less weak and inactive than it was before Lord Cnrzon s viceroyalty, and it is earnestly to be hoped that the Liberal party will not abandon that uniqae position which we have won from a oentnry of civilising work. BRITISH POSITION. At the present time our irfluence in Arabia is snch that, if we intrigued half as aotively as certain French and German newspapers profess to believe, we coaid shortly make it permanent. But as we shall no doubt continue to dcoline to take what wc can get, some other Power will assnrcd'y take it instead. There will be no lack of opportunities, for while there are certain to be oontinnal risings against Turkish misrule, the Arabs have shown themselves incapable of forming permanent States. Ge'many, by utilising her influence in the Ottoman Empire, is likely to snooeed to Tor key's position in Arabia. Hitherto she has apparently neglected the Red Sea, though railways to Sanaa and to Mecoa are wanted by the Government; but the Baghdad railway is intended to bring her in the near fntare to the shores of the Persian Galf, and the most desirable terminus for the railway is Koweit. This clean and thriving Arab town lies on the southern side of the shores of a large bay which forms the best natural harbour in the gulf. It has frequent communication with the interior, and I saw there some magnificent mares from Jebel Shammar which were destined to be shipped for the Bombay market. Thanks to our recent notion in defending it from Turkish attack, the chanoe that it will become a German port is now extremely remote. Its importance, however, is almost lost from the fact—commonly overlooked—that there is another natural harbour between Koweit and the mouth of the Shatt-el-Arab. This is the Khor Abdullah ; and the village of Um kasa, whioh may become the terminus of the railway, has lately been ocoupied by Turkish troops. The Liberal party would perhaps be oppO3ed, whether rightly or wrongly, to the acquisition by England of the wealth of Mesopotamia. It oan hardly be willing, however, to allow Germany a naval station on the Turkish side of the gulf, or another Port Arthur on the Persian coast. To say nothing of lo38 of prestige, which wonld not be confined to Persia and Turkey and Arabia, we should have to maintain another squadron for the protection of India — an expense possibly displeasing to those politicians who favour snch grac8fal concessions. The danger can only be averted by the maintenance of the Etrong position which we now hold in this port of the East (Mr. L. Baxton, in the "Standard").

div.head: NIGER AND LAKE CHAD. NEW ANGLO FRENCH CONVENTION.
div.p: The new Anglo-French Convention for the delimitation of the British and French posses-sions between the Niger and Lake Chad was signed at the Foreign Office last week by Sir Edward Grey, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairr, and M. Paul Cambon the French Ambassador. The first Convention, concluded in 1893, was fourd to leave France no practicable ronte between the Niger and Lake Chad. A seoond Convention followed in 1898, but it simply laid down a map boundary, before there had been any such exploration of the region in question, as could afford the two Governments precise topographical and ethnographical information. Various French expeditions, especially the Fonrreau-Lamy ex peditions, subsequently found even the second arrangement unsatisfactory. The boundary laid down was lound to cut native Sultanates in two, and divided populations subject to the game authority. Moreover, the French were still obliged to use Britiah territory to reaoh Lake Chad, and for reprovisioning their posts. The matter was consequently again taken ftp at the time of the negotations which led to the Anglo French Agreement of April 8, 1904, and it was agreed that, on the return of the Commissioners appointed to delimit the frontier, provided f.r in the Convention of 1898, changes should be made with a view to assuring France freedom of communication, account beirg taken of existing political divisions. A special commission met in London to consider these modifications, the British representafves being Sir Erio Barrington (Assistant Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs), the Hon. William Erskine (also of the Foreign Office), and Mr. Charles Strachey (of the Colonial Office); while the French de'e gates were M. Binger (of the Ministry of the Colonies) M. de Mannevile (of the Diplomatic Service), and Captain Tilho. It is the la- boars of this commisrim that were lately ratified by the latent Convention. A fresh mission will be sent out to demaroate the new frontier.

div.head: BJORNSON ON IBSEN.
div.p: When the news of Henrik Ibsen's death reaohed Copenhagen, a representative of "Poli- tiken" hastened to call on Bjdrnstjerne Bjorn- son, who is at present visiting the Danish capital. This is his acoonnt of the interview:— The old man advanoed to meet me, upright and powerful, radiant with health. He bade me be seated, and asked whether there was any partionlar news in the world. ' Yes," I said, ''Henrik Ibsen is dead." Bjonson sat silent for a moment ; then he said :— "So it has come *at last 1 Ah, poor fellow, he has seffered terribly. Towards the end he had lost even the power of speech. His only wish was to die. . . ." "Where and when did yon see him last ?" "It was when I was awarded the Nobel Prize. I always looked in npon him when anything notable had happened to me. He sat spent for a long time, with my hand between both of his, and at last he managed to stammer some oordial words." "If I now asked you to express in a few sentences yonr feeling as to Henrik Ibsen's work, what should you say ?" With a gesture of his delicate white hands, Bjornson seemed to ward off the question. "Oh," he said, "what oan I add to all that will now be said and written by all sorts o. celebrities all the world over ? I oan only repeat what I once said in a lecture : that Ibsen's works are like lighthouse?: they show yon where you must not sail, and they are the first things yon see when you look towards Norway. That seems to me pretty near the mark." "And which of his works do you think the most remarkable I" Without a moment's hesitation the poet re-plied :— " 'Ghosts !' It is there that he most lavishly develops his poetio gifts, and there that he goes deepest for his material. I do not know whether he oan be called the greatest of contemporary poets ; but the greatest Master- Builder, that he is. Look at 'The Wild Dock'! There is not a superfluous line in it; every word has its purpose. It is absolutely miraculous. But he worked and worked at each of his plays for two years on end, and did nothing else. It is the artistic element in Ibsen's works that will make them imperishable." Bjornson ended by expressing regret that he ooald not attend the faneral, being engaged to leotare in Denmark on Jane 2nd and succeeding days. This interview, and especially the pathetic picture it shows ns of Ibsen sitting with Bjdrnson's hand in his and struggling to □tter his oongratnlations on the good fortane that had befallen his brother poet, ought to silence the constantly reourring tittle-tattle as to jealons enmity between the two men. There may be jealousies among the little hills,bnt the great peaks stand faoe to face and rejoice in each other's greatnes0

div.head: FIRE ON THE S.8. SOMALI.
div.p: Daring her return voyage from Calontta to London last week a serious fire broke out on the P. & 0. liner Somali in the Bay of Biscay. The Somali, which left Marseilles on May 24, entered the Bay of Biscay on Monday evening. At half-past three on Tuesday morning a dense fog came on, and the vessel slowed down. At a quarter to eight smoke was found issuing from the hatohways, and it was discovered that the cargo in hold No. 4 (after) was on fire immediately under the passengers' baggage. The flame) got a firm hold of the cargo, which was mainly jute and linseed, and, notwithstanding that all the available hose was turned OD, they reaohed the baggage, and spread to the purser's room, and the refrigerating chambers. The hatchways were opened on Wednesday morning and the passengers' luggage brought out. It presented a remarkable sight, almost eveiy package being rained by fire or water, and many absolutely oharred to a cinder. In explanation of the baggage being soaked through, it was stated that, finding it impossible to reaoh the fire effeotaally with the hose, the oaptain had ordered the sea-cocks to be opened, in order to flood the hold. 3 he npshot was that the Somali, with the whole of her stores destroyed (for the fire had made a olean sweep of the store-rooms), made for Plymouth. She arrived in the Sonnd on Wednesday evening at nine o'clock with about 27ft. of water in the after hold and her stern deep in the water.

div.head: BOND IN BRICKWORK
div.p: There are all kinds of bonds — Turkish, Egyptian, English, and the bond of good- fellowship — besides the bond in briokwork, of which Mr. Robert Williams, F.R.I.B.A., writes with much point in a large quarto pamphlet which has just come to hand from Messrs. Whitehead,Morris and Co, printers and publishers of Alexandria. The broohnre is printed in three languages — French, Arabic, and English. There are 16 fall-page plates and an elaborate frontispieoe, comprising in all some 25 drawings. The book is dedicated to Messrs. Edward and Joseph Davies Bryan, "who entrusted the author with his first commission in Egypt," to Mr. G. B. Alderson, "that friend of the people,"and the masons of Egypt, "with the earnest desire of strengthening the bond of comradeship wh'ch should always exist between the arohiteot and the workman." The object of the author is the assisting of the masons of Alexandria in the prodnotion of good work, ahent which he says in his "Preliminary Notes" :— "A good oonscienoe does not approve of bad work ; moreover, there is no pleasure in the doing of bad work, but our work should be worth doing and be of itself pleasant to do. The building of a brick wall in bad bond cannot bring pleasure to the mason, whereas, the oonsoioasness that the wall is well built aud that it serves some useful purpose to one's fellow-citizens must be a source of pleasure to the man who built it. The work of the architect is above all a work of co-operation. Without the assistance of the labourer who digs the trenches for the foundation, the mason who builds the walls, and the oarver who oarves the ornamentation, the designs of the arohiteot, howeverDeaatifal they may be, ooald never be realised. Personnally I feel indebted to every workman who assists me in realising my designs, and it is because I wish that b3th they and myself should always do good, honest work that 1 hope the masons of Alexandria will do me the honour of studying these few pages, and especially the diagram?." The illustrations are preceded by a plan of a wall "built in very bad bond," which is given as a warning against bad bonding and is not to be imitated. The author shows the wastefulness and expense of bad work as oom pared with good work with the same materials. We are taken through a course cf briok-work aud are shown with great olearness how to bond walls from one to three bricks in thiokness. The title of the book is printed on one side in English and on the other iu Arabia, and stands within a perspective view of an Arabio doorway designed to be built in brick aud of which details are given within the book, the production of which must have been costly, for the drawings and designs have bseu especially prepared for this work. The price (P.T. 20) is not prohibitive and we think that every mason in Egypt as well as every person having the direotion ot building should lose no time in possessing themselves of a oopy

Then a severe oold settled on my ohest and developed into a haoking cough, whioh laid the foundation of a serious illness that might have ended in my death but for Dr. Williams' Pink Pills." "My chest was full of tearing pains," con-tinued Mrs. Davis, 241,8yston-street, Leicester, "and my lungs beoame terribly inflamed. I fell into a weak, low, disheartened state. My cough worried me day and night; I could obtain no rest. At last I could hardly walk. My eyesight, too, was strangely affected. I had doctor's advice, but beoame a physical wreok. Every mouthful of food caused torture. My blood turned to water ; my hands and feet were always cold ; my lips and cheeks livid ; my tee'h ached, and I was subject to violent neuralgia. The least exertion made me breathless ; my heart wonld oease, and then suddenly thump faiiously. I underwent hospital treatment, and learned that my illness was general debility, aggravated by obstinate and negleoted acsemia. ' Everything was done to relieve my suffer-ings, but the illness had taken a strong hold on me. After two operations, I attempted to get abont again, bnt was very soon reduced to a weaker state than ever. I looked awful. Once I collapsed suddenly and had to be driven home in a cab. I thought death would shortly ensue. The oough seemed to tear me to pieces. When friends suggested Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People 1 refused, for everything else had failed. However, I began taking them, and soon my ooogh mended. My appetite improved wonderfnlly, and I could digest and retain food, and gained flesh. Life seemed to have pleasure in it, and I did not find exercise or work fatiguieg. I bought more pills ; my colour returned ; I had no neuralgia. My sight beoame stronger, and I regained my former vigour and strength. Now I am completely well. I feel ten years younger, thanks to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People."
